intro: Crypsinus bakeri, commonly known as the Baker's crypts, is a rare and enigmatic plant species native to the high-altitude regions of the Andes. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its compact growth habit and finely divided leaves. The plant produces small, white flowers arranged in umbels, typical of its family, and is often found in rocky, well-drained soils. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered endangered and requires conservation efforts to protect its fragile ecosystem. Its botanical study contributes to the understanding of alpine plant adaptations and biodiversity in extreme environments.
